awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Nature's machinery through the prism of physics, biology, chemistry and engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Clemson University, located in Clemson, SC, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. Program participants work with faculty, postdocs, graduate students, and other undergraduates on collaborative research exploring biology through the prism of physics, biology, chemistry and engineering (e.g., computational and experimental approaches for molecular insights into amyloid aggregation, studies of how missense mutations affect protein-DNA binding affinity, and quantifying properties of active polymer networks and gels from cytoskeletal proteins). The focus is on cross-disciplinary training; while each participant has a specific project with their own mentor, participants are paired to work together within a larger collaboration. The program includes a biophysics boot-camp, seminar series, workshops on research tools and professional development, journal club, off-campus field trips, ethics training, and cohort-building activities. Participants regularly present their contributions to collaborators and hear about the research of their peers. Each participant presents a poster of their own work adjacent to their collaborator's poster at the final summer research symposium, writes their own research manuscript, and is encouraged to present their work at scientific conferences. Participants also engage in outreach activities throughout the summer.
 
It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities and from underrepresented minority groups, will be trained in the program. The program is designed to give participants a sense of the mutual contributions that physical scientists can make to biology, and that biologists can make to the physical sciences. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting www.clemson.edu/physics/biophysics-reu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Joshua Alper at alper@clemson.edu) or co-PI (Dr. Hugo Sanabria at hsanabr@clemson.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this REU Site were to provide three cohorts of ten participants, each with a ten-week program focused on student learning through mentored research experiences on collaborative, interdisciplinary projects with faculty from the Departments of Physics and Astronomy, Bioengineering, Materials Science and Engineering, Chemistry, Biological Sciences, and Biochemistry and Genetics.

Our program hosted 36 participants from 2019-2023, with an acceptance of < 10% and 100% participation from outside Clemson University. The background of our participants was 50% from biological sciences and the remaining in physical sciences. 58% were female participants, 67% were URMs and Asian Americans, and 59% were participants from non-R1 institutions. 

Goal 1: Encourage and enable participants to pursue interdisciplinary research careers.

Outcomes 1: Of 36 participants (2019-2023), 26 obtained B.S. degrees. Among graduates, 73% (19/26) are pursuing graduate studies, 12% (3/26) are furthering their education through diverse programs, internships, or post-baccalaureate initiatives, 12% (3/26) are in the biotechnology industry, and only 4% (1/26) have not provided post-graduation updates.

Goal 2: Provide participants with important and feasible projects done and mentored collaboratively by biological and physical scientists.

Outcomes 2: Over the funded period, participants worked on 18 different collaborative projects with 36 individual research outcomes. The collaborative projects involved faculty from eight different departments in two colleges at Clemson University.

Goal 3: Train participants to communicate science clearly. 

Outcomes 3: All 36 participants delivered at least one oral project update presentation during the ten-week summer, a poster presentation at the summer symposium, and submitted a draft report of the activities formatted for publication.

Goal 4: Provide career development advice, research skills, and mentorship.

Outcome 4: 34 out of 36 participants received a Biophysics Bootcamp. 35 Participants received Research skills and professional development workshops, and all participated in journal clubs, research safety, and responsible conduct of research.

Intellectual Merit (IM): This REU IM was to advance knowledge within the field of biophysics by broadening the pool of talented young scientists interested in and experiencing interdisciplinary research. Participants gained a depth of expertise not available as part of their undergraduate curriculum, which helped them in their graduate or professional careers.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes: Participants published 4 peer-reviewed articles, 2 conference processing, and 1 article is currently under review. In addition, 10 participants presented their work at national or international conferences.

Broader Impacts (BI): The BI of the REU was to encourage promising young scientists to pursue a career in the challenging and evolving field of biophysics. Due to its highly interdisciplinary and collaborative nature, this REU will encourage an atmosphere of cooperation amongst future leaders in the field.

Broader Impact Outcomes:  As part of the REU, we developed a new curriculum for the Biophysics Bootcamp and a Biophysics Concept Inventory for evaluating learning outcomes in this interdisciplinary field. In addition, through two REPS supplements, we support two postbaccalaureate trainees who are currently in grad school.
